title: (x) Bike Month NYC 2008 rounded tech sans - Naiv {James Langdon}
content:
Hate for my first post to be a request for help, but there’s something that says friendly future about this face and I’d love to know if it’s publicly available.

[http://bikemonthnyc.org/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122044223/http:/bikemonthnyc.org/ "http://bikemonthnyc.org/") for more possible instances.

And since I’m asking, what’s the proper term for the line through the “O”?

Thanks, and I’ll try to contribute something next time.

Jeff

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [logo\_2008.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122044223/http:/typophile.com/files/logo_2008.png) | 5.42 KB |

 [‹ I'm close, I think..](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122044223/http:/www.typophile.com/node/48129 "Go to previous forum topic") [uark ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122044223/http:/www.typophile.com/node/48122 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Jeff Kirsch

comments.content:
<cite>And since I’m asking, what’s the proper term for the line through the “O”?</cite>

That is the most obvious script element to this font. In calligraphic terms it would either be the start of a connecting stroke or a flourish, but since it doesn’t extend out of the letter to do either I’m not sure what it should be called.  
It is an odd character but I like it.

James - Thanks for the quick ID.

Justin - I was thinking flourish too, but stumped by its internal nature.
